text.p: Colombia's peso rose 3.7 to close at 995.7 pesos to the dollar as greenbacks flooded currency markets on Friday, interbank traders said.
"The rate opened around 1,000 pesos to the dollar, but about 10am the dollar began to dive as industry pumped export earnings into the market," a private bank trader said.

He said the key oil, coffee and coal sectors were all trading in greenbacks. Although the central bank's co-director Hernando Jose Gomez said the central bank would intervene more heavily in 1997 to ensure the devaluation of the peso to a more realistic rate, it did not step in on Friday.
"There was little demand for dollars and there was little chance of reining in the peso's rise," another interbank dealer said.
Dealers reported 355 trades worth $141.7 million. The peso opened at 999.7 to the dollar. It hit an intraday low of 1,000.15 and closed at the high of 995.7, its highest since January 5.
